content.description:
Climb up and right up the juggy rail leading to a big move to the lip, followed by a sea of brittle breaking chickenheads.

If anyone knows of a name or previous ascent, please do not hesitate to let me know!
content.protection: Many pads and a psyched friend.
content.location: Start on jugs on the left side of the southwest-facing side of the boulder.

content.description:
This climbs like a mini-sport route. You have a difficult crux followed by a quick shake into an easier but committing crux. It's got the best landing of the whole boulder!

If anyone knows of a name or previous ascent, please do not hesitate to let me know!
content.location: This sit starts on the left side of the west face of the boulder.

content.description:
There is really fun movement on this climb! It is a must do for those that appreciate movement more than rock quality. This route could be dangerous if you broke a hold and fell off the top.

If anyone knows of a name or previous ascent, please do not hesitate to let me know!
content.protection: Grabbing the thickest parts of the holds and lots of pads.
content.location: This is on the southeast side of the boulder. Start on a sandy hueco.

content.description:
Start sitting, and traverse up and right, following the jug seam until you traverse around the lip.

If anyone knows of a name or previous ascent, please do not hesitate to let me know!
content.location: This starts on the bottom left side of the west face with the dark patina rock.

content.description:
Sit start with hands matched on large jug/hueco.  From there, make a large move up to a side-pull sloper.  Then set your feet and hit the sloping lip.  The remaining top out works through crimps and bumps which access a positive rail high up the slab.  Success depends upon hitting the first move just right.

The easiest way down is the same way this problem climbs up.  It's an 8 foot drop-down, not bad with a few pads.
content.protection: Pad or two and a spot, the landing is great though.
content.location: Center of Grandmaster Boulder's north-face.  The problem starts where a small fir sapling has taken root.
